Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616)552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
On 3/24/21, youth was given time to calm down after verbally escalating. After two
minutes, staff checked on youth who was no longer in the hallway. Staff could not
locate youth inside facility. The door at the end of the hallway was not secure and it
as determined youth was able to leave the facility. Youth was unable to be located
in the surrounding area.
On 3/26/2021 I received the allegations submitted by the Chief Administrator
documenting the events as described in the initial notification and adding that the
door was checked after the Youth A left the building and it was secure.
INVESTIGATION:
On 3/24/2021 I received a notification from Staff that Youth A went AWOL from the
Antonin program at approximately 3:30pm by “somehow” escaping through a long
hallway back door. Staff were unable to locate her outside.
On 3/29/2021 I completed an unannounced visit to the facility at approximately
10:30am. While at the facility, I checked the door from which the youth was able to
AWOL and found it to be secure and locked. I attempted to open the door three
times, waiting several minutes between each attempt, and it remained locked each
time.
Document Review
On 3/26/2021 I received and reviewed an Incident Report (IR) written by Staff 1
documenting that on 3/24/2021 Youth A was escalated and asking that staff let her
into her room. Staff did not due to her history of self-harm but told her they would
give her space and left the hallway. Less than 3 minutes later, staff returned to the
hallway and Youth A was gone. Youth A returned to the facility at approximately
6:30pm. The following morning, it was discovered that the door at the end of the
hallways leading to an unsecure door to the outside was malfunctioning and the lock
was “not latching properly.”
On 3/26/2021 I received and reviewed a work order showing that the door was
repaired on 3/25/2021.
Interviews
Chief Administrator - On 3/26/2021 during a virtual meeting regarding a different
issue, Chief Administrator reported that, when it was discovered that Youth A was
missing, the staff could not initially determine how she left because the door was
secure ad locked. Youth A left through the door again the next day at which time it
was discovered that the door was not latching properly. Facilities staff were notified
and determined that the door was “sagging” due to the building settling, resulting in
the door malfunctioning. The door was immediately repaired.
Staff 1- On 3/28/2021 I interviewed Staff 1 and Youth A in person. Staff 1 reported
that, on 3/24/2021, Youth A was upset and escalated. Staff 1 gave her space by
3

leaving Youth A alone in her bedroom hallway. Less than 3 minutes later, Staff 1
returned to the hallway and Youth A was gone. Staff 1 did not know how she could
have left the building, so she checked all of the bedrooms before checking the door
at the end of the hallway which leads to an unsecured exit from the building. Staff 1
stated that she was able to push the door open despite the red light being on,
indicating that the door is locked. She stated that she left the building to look for
Youth A and when she returned to the building, again tried to open the door, but it
was locked. She stated that she tried it multiple times and it remained secure. The
following day, Youth A left through the door again, but never left the building. The
door was repaired that same day.
Youth A – Youth A reported that she was in her bedroom hallway and heard Staff 2
say that Youth A wanted to AWOL and that the door at the end of the hallway was
unlocked. Youth A then opened the door and left the building. She stated that she
did not know the door was malfunctioning until she heard Staff 2 say that it was. The
door was locked after she returned, but she was able to push it open again the
following day. She stated that the door is fixed and secure now.
Staff 2 - On 3/30/2021 I interviewed Staff 2 by phone. She reported that she was not
aware that the door at the end of Staff 1’s bedroom hallway wasn’t working properly
until after the incident. She stated that she was in the milieu conducting a house
meeting at the time of the incident and didn’t know the youth went AWOL until an
hour after the fact. She stated that, after she found out about the incident, she
checked the door throughout the remainder of her shift, and it was always locked.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4407 Facility and premises maintenance.
(1) A facility and premises shall be maintained in a clean,
comfortable, and safe condition. The facility shall be
located on land that is properly drained.
ANALYSIS: A secure door at the facility was not functioning properly
allowing for a youth to AWOL from the building.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
